turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Hello, what's your name?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Eve. Eve Harrington.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You said forty-seven minutes. You'll never make it.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I told you a lie. We'll make it easily. Margo's got no more conception of time than a halibut.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I just wondered.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Just wondered what?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Why.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Why what?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Why you have to go out there.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I don't have to. I want to.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Is it the money?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Eighty percent of it will go for taxes.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Then why? Why, if you're the best and most successful young director in the Theater-

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: The Theatuh, the Theatuh-  - what book of rules says the Theater exists only within some ugly buildings crowded into one square mile of New York City? Or London, Paris or Vienna?  Listen, junior. And learn. Want to know what the Theater is? A flea circus. Also opera. Also rodeos, carnivals, ballets, Indian tribal dances, Punch and Judy, a one-man band - all Theater. Wherever there's magic and make-believe and an audience - there's Theater. Donald Duck, Ibsen, and The Lone Ranger, Sarah Bernhardt, Poodles Hanneford, Lunt and Fontanne, Betty Grable, Rex and Wild, and Eleanora Duse. You don't understand them all, you don't like them all, why should you? The Theater's for everybody - you included, but not exclusively - so don't approve or disapprove. It may not be your Theater, but it's Theater of somebody, somewhere.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I just asked a simple question.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: And I shot my mouth off. Nothing personal, junior, no offense...  ... it's just that there's so much bushwah in this Ivory Green Room they call the Theatuh - sometimes it gets up around my chin...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: But Hollywood. You mustn't stay there.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: It's only one picture deal.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: So few come back...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Yeah. They keep you under drugs out there with armed guards...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I read George Jean Nathan every week.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Also Addison deWitt.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Every day.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You didn't have to tell me.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Ah...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I have a suggestion.  There's really not much time left - I mean, you haven't had a minute alone yet, and - well, I could take care of everything here and meet you at the gate with the ticket... if you'd like.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I think we'd like very much. Sure you won't mind?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Of course not.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Thanks for your help... good luck.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Goodbye, Mr. Sampson.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Yes. Yes, it does.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: It means concentration of ambition, desire, and sacrifice such as no other profession demands... And I'll agree that the man or woman who accepts those terms can't be ordinary, can't be - just someone. To give so much for almost always so little...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: - little things here and there, it doesn't matter. You can be proud of yourself, you've got a right to be.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Are you proud of me, Bill?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I'll admit I was worried when Max called. I had my doubts.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You shouldn't have had any doubts.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: - after all, the other day was one scene, the woods are full of one scene sensations. But you did it. With work and patience, you'll be a fine actress. If that's what you want to be.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Is that what you want me to be?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I'm talking about you. And what you want.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: So am I.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: What have I got to do with it?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Everything.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: The names I've been called. But never Svengali.  Good luck.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Don't run away, Bill.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: From what would I be running?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You're always after truth - on the stage. What about off?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I'm for it.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Then face it. I have. Since that first night - here - in the dressing room.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: When I told you what every young actress should know.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: When you told me that whatever I became, it would be because of you-

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Your make-up's a little heavy.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: - and for you.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You're quite a girl.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You think?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I'm in love with Margo. Hadn't you heard?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You hear all kinds of things.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I'm only human, rumors to the contrary. And I'm as curious as the next man...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Find out.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Only thing, what I go after, I want to go after. I don't want it to come after me.

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: Lemme fix you a drink.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: No thanks, Birdie.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Margo does not play a lunatic, Birdie.

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: I know. She just keeps hearin' her dead father play the banjo.

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: The bed looks like a dead animal act. Which one is sables?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: But she just got here...

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: She's on her way. With half the men in the joint.  It's only a fur coat...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: What did you expect - live sables?

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: A diamond collar, gold sleeves - you know, picture people...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Bill says actors out there eat just as infrequently as here-

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: They can always grab oranges off trees. This you can't do in Times Square...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It was Fort Sumter they fired on-

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: I never played Fort Sumter.

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: You need new girdles.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Buy some.

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: The same size?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Of course!

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: Well. I guess a real tight girdle help when you're playin' a lunatic.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: How do you do, my dear.

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: Oh, brother.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: And this is my good friend and companion, Miss Birdie Coonan.

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: Oh, brother.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Miss Coonan...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I'm sure you must have things to do in the bathroom, Birdie dear.

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: If I haven't, I'll find something till you're normal.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: There are some human experiences, Birdie, that do not take place in a vaudeville house - and that even a fifth-rate vaudevillian should understand and respect!  I want to apologize for Birdie's-

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: You don't have to apologize for me!  I'm sorry if I hurt your feelings. It's just my way of talkin'...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: She, too, is a great admirer of yours.

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: Imagine. All this admiration in just one room.

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: Kill the people.  Got your key?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: See you home...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You bought the new girdles a size smaller. I can feel it.

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: Something maybe grew a size bigger.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: When we get home you're going to get into one of those girdles and act for two and half hours.

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: I couldn't get into the girdle in two an' a half hours...

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: Adorable. We now got everything a dressing room needs except a basketball hoop.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Just because you can't even work a zipper. It was very thoughtful, Eve, and I appreciate it-

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: If I may so bold as to say something - did you ever hear the word "union"?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Behind in your dues? How much?

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: I haven't got a union. I'm slave labor.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: But the wardrobe women have got one. And next to a tenor, a wardrobe woman is the touchiest thing in show business-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Oh-oh.

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: She's got two things to do - carry clothes an' press 'em wrong - an' just let anybody else muscle in...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Birdie-

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: Hmm?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You don't like Eve, do you?

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: Do you want an argument or an answer?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: An answer.

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: Now you want an argument.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: She works hard.

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: Night an' day.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: She's loyal and efficient-

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: Like an agent with one client.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: She thinks only for me...  ... doesn't she?

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: Well... let's say she thinks only about you, anyway...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: How do you mean that?

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: I'll tell you how. Like - let's see - like she was studyin' you, like you were a play or a book or a set of blueprints. How you walk, talk, think, eat, sleep-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I'm sure that's very flattering, Birdie, and I'm sure there's nothing wrong with that!

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: You all put together?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: My back's open.  Did the extra help get here?

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: There's some loose characters dressed like maids and butlers. Who'd you call - the William Morris Agency?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You're not being funny, I could get actors for less. What about the food?

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: The caterer had to back for hors d'oeuvres-  Voila.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: That French ventriloquist taught you a lot, didn't he?

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: There was nothing he didn't know.  There's a message from the bartender. Does Miss Channing know we ordered domestic gin by mistake?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: The only thing I ordered by mistake is the guests.  They're domestic, too, and they don't care what they drink as long as it burns... where's Bill? He's late.

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: Late for what?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Don't be dense. The party.

turns.speaker: BIRDIE
turns.text: I ain't dense. And he's been here twenty minutes.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Well, I certainly think it's odd he hasn't even come up...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Miss Harrington...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: I - I guess I fell asleep.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Please don't have me arrested, please! I didn't steal anything - you can search me!

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: How did you get in here?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: I hid outside in the hall till the maid came to turn down your bed. She must've forgot something and when she went to get it, she left the door open. I sneaked in and hid till she finished. Then I just looked around - and pretty soon I was afraid somebody'd notice the lights were on so I turned them off - and then I guess, I fell asleep.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You were just looking around...

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: That's all.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: You probably won't believe me.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Probably not.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: It was for my report.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: What report? To whom?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: About how you live, what kind of clothes you wear - what kind of perfume and books - things like that. You know the Eve Harrington clubs - that they've got in most of the girls' high schools?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I've heard of them.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Ours was one of the first. Erasmus Hall. I'm the president.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Erasmus Hall. That's in Brooklyn, isn't it?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Lots of actresses come from Brooklyn. Barbara Stanwyck, Susan Hayward - of course, they're just movie stars.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: You're going to Hollywood - aren't you?  From the trunks you're packing, you must be going to stay a long time.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I might.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: That spilled drink is going to ruin your carper.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: The maid'll fix it in the morning.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: I'll just pick up the broken glass.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Don't bother.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: How'd you get all the way up here from Brooklyn?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Subway.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: How long does it take?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: With changing and everything, a little over an hour.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: It's after one now. You won't get home till all hours.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: I don't care if I never get home.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: That's the door.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: You rest. I'll get it...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: So there you are. It seemed odd, suddenly, your not being there...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Why should you think I wouldn't be?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Why should you be? After all, six nights a week - for weeks - of watching even Margo Channing enter and leave a theater-

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I hope you don't mind my speaking to you...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Not at all.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I've seen you so often - it took every bit of courage I could raise-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: To speak to just a playwright's wife? I'm the lowest form of celebrity...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You're Margo Channing's best friend. You and your husband are always with her - and Mr. Sampson... what's he like?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Bill Sampson? He's - he's a director.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: He's the best.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: He'll agree with you. Tell me, what do you between the time Margo goes in and comes out? Just huddle in that doorway and wait?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh, no. I see the play.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You see the play? You've seen the play every performance?  But, don't you find it - I mean apart from everything else - don't you find it expensive?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Standing room doesn't cost much. I manage.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I'm going to take you to Margo...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh, no...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: She's got to meet you-

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: No, I'd be imposing on her, I'd be just another tongue-tied gushing fan...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: There isn't another like you, there couldn't be-

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: But if I'd known... maybe some other time... I mean, looking like this.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You look just fine...  ... by the way. What's your name?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Eve. Eve Harrington.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I thought you'd forgotten about me.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Not at all.  Margo, this is Eve Harrington.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Hello, Miss Channing.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: My husband...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: If I only knew how...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Try...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Eve... why don't you start at the beginning?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: It couldn't possibly interest you.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You're not going, are you?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I think I'd better. It's been - well, I can hardly find the words to say how it's been...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Good night, Eve. I hope I see you again soon-

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'll be at the old stand, tomorrow matinee-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Not just that way. As a friend...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'd like that.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Now who's show up at this hour? It's time people went home - hold that coat up...  ... whose is it?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Some Hollywood movie star, her plane got in late.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Discouraging, isn't it? Women with furs like that where it never gets cold...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Hollywood.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Tell me, Eve - how are things with you? Happy?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: There should be a new word for happiness. Being here with Miss Channing has been - I just can't say, she's been so wonderful, done so much for me-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Lloyd says Margo compensates for underplaying on the stage by overplaying reality...  ... next to that sable, my new mink seems like an old bedjacket...  ... you've done your share, Eve. You've worked wonders with Margo...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Mrs. Richards.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Karen.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Karen...  ... isn't it awful, I'm about to ask you for another favor - after all you've already done.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Nobody's done so much, Eve, you've got to stop thinking of yourself as one of the Hundred Neediest Cases... what is it?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Well... Miss Channing's affairs are in such good shape... there isn't enough to keep me as busy as I should be, really - not that I've ever considered anything that would take me away from her... but the other day - when I heard Mr. Fabian tell Miss Channing that her understudy was going to have a baby, and they'd have to replace her...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: ... you want to be Margo's new understudy.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I don't let myself think about it, even-  - but I do know the part so well, and every bit of the staging, there'd be no need to break in a new girl-  - but suppose I had to go on one night? To an audience that came to see Margo Channing. No, I couldn't possibly...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Don't worry too much about that. Margo just doesn't miss performances. If she can walk, crawl or roll - she plays.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: The show must go on.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: No, dear. Margo must go on.  As a matter of fact, I see no reason why you shouldn't be Margo's understudy...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Do you think Miss Channing would approve?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I think she would cheer.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: But Mr. Richards and Mr. Sampson-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: They'll do as they're told.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Then - would you talk to Mr. Fabian about it?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You won't forget it?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I won't forget.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I seem to be forever thanking you for something, don't I?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You mustn't mind Margo too much, even if I do...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: But there must be some reason, something I've done without knowing...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: The reason is Margo and don't try to figure it out. Einstein couldn't.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: If I thought I'd offended her, of all people-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Eve. I'm fond of Margo too. But I know Margo. And every now and then there is nothing I want to do so much as to kick her right square in the pants.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Well - if she's got to pick on someone, I'd just as soon it was me.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Karen...  ... you won't forget, will you? What we talked about before?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: No, Eve, I won't forget...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: May I have your coat?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Don't bother, I can take it up myself...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Please...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Eve. I've heard the most wonderful things about your performance-

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Mostly relief that I managed to stagger through it at all...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: We're having lunch with a movie talent scout.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: They certainly don't waste much time.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Nothing definite yet - it's just to have lunch.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I was wondering whether you'd come at all..

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Don't get up.  And don't act as if I were the queen mother.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I don't expect you to be pleasant.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I don't intend to be.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Can't we sit down? Just for a minute...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I've got a lot to say. And none of it is easy.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: There can't be very much-

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh, but there is-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: - and easy or not, I won't believe a word.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Why shouldn't you?  Please sit down.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You know, I've always considered myself a very clever girl. Smart. Good head on my shoulders, that sort of thing, never the wrong word at the wrong time... but then, I'd never met Addison deWitt.  I remember once I had a tooth pulled. They gave me some anaesthetic - I don't remember the name - and it affected me in a strange way. I heard myself saying things I wasn't even thinking... as if my mind were someplace outside of my body, and couldn't control what I did or said-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: - and you felt just like that talking to Addison.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: In a way. You find yourself trying to say what you mean, but somehow the words change - and they become his words - and suddenly you're not saying what you mean, but what he means-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Do you expect me to believe that you didn't say any of those things - that they were all Addison?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: No! I don't expect you to believe anything. Except that the responsibility is mine. And the disgrace.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Let's not get over-dramatic.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You've really got a low opinion of me, haven't you? We'll I'll give you some pleasant news. I've been told off in no uncertain terms all over town. Miss Channing should be happy to hear that. To know how loyal her friends are - how much more loyal they are than she had a right to expect me to be...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Eve... don't cry.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'm not crying.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Tell me. How did your lunch turn out - with the man from Hollywood?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Some vague promises of a test, that's all - if a particular part should come along, one of those things-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: But the raves about your performance-

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: - an understudy's performance.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Well. I think you're painting the picture a little darker than it is, really. If nothing else - and don't underestimate him - you have a powerful friend in Addison.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: He's not my friend. You were my friends...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: He can help you.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I wish I'd never met him, I'd like him to be dead... I want my friends back.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Eve. I - I don't think you meant to cause unhappiness. But you did. More to yourself, perhaps - as it turned out - than to anyone else...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'll never get over it.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Yes, you will. You Theater people always do. Nothing is forever in the Theater. Love or hate, success or failure - whatever it is, it's here, it flares up and burns hot - and then it's gone.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I wish I could believe that.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Give yourself time. Don't worry too much about what people think, you're very young and very talented...  ... and, believe it or not, if there's anything I can do-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I think I know...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Something most important you can do.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You want to play "Cora." You want me to tell Lloyd I think you should play it.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: If you told him so, he'd give me the part. He said he would.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: After all you've said... don't you know the part was written for Margo?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: It could have been - fifteen years ago. It's my part now.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You talk just as Addison said you did.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: "Cora" is my part. You've got to tell Lloyd it's for me.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I don't think anything in the world could make me say that.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Addison wants me to play it.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Over my dead body...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: That won't be necessary. Addison knows how Margo happen to miss that performance - how I happened to know she'd miss it in time to call him and notify every paper in town...  ... it's quite a story. Addison could make quite a thing of it - imagine how snide and vicious he could get and still write nothing but the truth. I had a time persuading him...  ... you'd better sit down. You look a bit wobbly.  If I play "Cora," Addison will never tell what happened - in or out of print. A simple exchange of favors. And I'm so happy I can do something for you - at long last...  Your friendship with Margo - your deep, close friendship - what would happen to it, do you think, if she knew the chap trick you'd played on her - for my benefit? And you and Lloyd - how long, even in the Theater, before people forgot what happened - and trusted you again?  No... it would be so much easier on everyone concerned, if I were to play "Cora." And so much better theater, too...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: A part in a play. You'd do all that - just for a part in a play.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'd do much more - for a part that good.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: She knows enough not to be here.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: But not all of it - not that Lloyd and I are going to be married.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Congratulations, Eve.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Thank you, Karen.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Hello, Miss Harrington.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: How do you do, Mr. Richards.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: No, thank you.  Yes. I've seen every performance.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Every performance? Then - am I safe in assuming you like it?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'd like anything Miss Channing played...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: How'd hear about it?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: There was an item in the Times. i like the title. 'Footsteps on the Ceiling'.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Let's get back to this one. Have you really seen every performance?  Why? I'm curious...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Well... it started with the play before this one...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: 'Remembrance'.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I guess it started back home. Wisconsin, that is. There was just mum, and dad - and me. I was the only child, and I made believe a lot when I was a kid - I acted out all sorts of things... what they were isn't important. But somehow acting and make-believe began to fill up my life more and more, it got so that I couldn't tell the real from the unreal except that the unreal seemed more real to me... I'm talking a lot of gibberish, aren't I?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Not at all...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Farmers were poor in those days, that's what dad was - a farmer. I had to help out. So I quit school and I went to Milwaukee. I became a secretary. In a brewery.  When you're a secretary in a brewery - it's pretty hard to make believe you're anything else. Everything is beer. It wasn't much fun, but it helped at home -  and there was a Little Theater Group... like a drop of rain in the desert. That's where I met Eddie. He was a radio technician. We played 'Liliom' for three performances, I was awful - then the war came, and we got married. Eddie was in the air force - and they sent him to the South Pacific. You were with the O.W.I., weren't you Mr. Richards?  That's what 'Who's Who' says... well, with Eddie gone, my life went back to beer. Except for a letter a week. One week Eddie wrote he had a leave coming up. I'd saved my money and vacation time. I went to San Francisco to meet him.  Eddie wasn't there. They forwarded the telegram from Milwaukee - the one that came from Washington to say that Eddie wasn't coming at all. That Eddie was dead...  ... so I figured I'd stay in San Francisco. i was alone, but couldn't go back without Eddie. I found a job. And his insurance helped... and there were theaters in San Francisco. And one night Margo Channing came to play in 'Remembrance'... and I went to see it. And - well - here I am...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: It's been a real pleasure, Eve.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I hope so, Mr. Richards. Good night...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Back to Copacabana. But Eve. Margo, let me tell you about Eve-

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I was dreadful, Miss Channing, believe me - I have no right to be anyone's understudy, much less yours...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Please, don't misunderstand me, Mr. Richards. I think that part of Miss Channing's greatness lies in her ability to choose the best plays... your new play is for Miss Channing, isn't it, Mr. Richards?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Of course it is.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Well. If I didn't come to see the play, I wouldn't have anywhere else to go.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: There are other plays...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Not with you in them. Not by Mr. Richards...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Did you see it here in New York?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: San Francisco. It was the last week. I went one night... the most important night in my life - until this one. Anyway... I found myself going the next night - and the next and the next. Every performance. Then, when the show went East - I went East.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: No, don't go...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: The four of you must have so much to say to each other - with Mr. Sampson leaving...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Stick around. Please. Tell you what - we'll put Stanislavsky on his plane, you and I, then go somewhere and talk.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Well - if I'm not in the way...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I won't be a minute.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What - again?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I could watch you play that last scene a thousand times and cry every time-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Performance number one thousand of this one - if I play it that long - will take place in a well-padded booby hatch...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I must say you can certainly tell Mr. Sampson's been gone a month.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You certainly can. Especially if you're me between now and tomorrow morning...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I mean the performance. Except for you, you'd think he'd never even directed it - it's disgraceful the way they change everything around...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Well, teacher's away and actors will be actors...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: During your second act scene with your father, Roger Ferraday's supposed to stay way upstage at the arch. He's been coming closer down every night...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: When he gets too close, I'll spit in his eye.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You haven't noticed my latest bit of interior decorating...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Well, you've done so much... what's new?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: The curtains. I made them myself.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: They are lovely. Aren't they lovely, Birdie?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: While you're cleaning up, I'll take this to the wardrobe mistress-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Don't bother. Mrs. Brown'll be along for it in a minute.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: No trouble at all.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Well - what do you think of my elegant new suit?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Very becoming. It looks better on you than it did on me.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I can imagine... you know, all it needed was some taking in here and letting out there - are you sure you won't want it yourself?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Quite sure. I find it just a bit too - too "Seventeenish" for me...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh, come now, as though you were an old lady... I'm on my way. Is there anything more you've thought of-?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: There's the script to go back to the Guild-

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I've got it.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: - and those checks or whatever it is for the income tax man.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Right here.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It seems I can't think of a thing you haven't thought of...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: That's my job.  See you at tea time...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Eve...  ... by any chance, did you place a call from me to Bill for midnight California time?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh, golly. And I forgot to tell you-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Yes, dear. You forgot all about it.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Well, I was sure you'd want to, of course, being his birthday, and you've been so busy these past few days, and last night I meant to tell you before you went out with the Richards - and I guess I was asleep when you got home...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Yes, I guess you were. It - it was very thoughtful of you, Eve.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Mr. Sampson's birthday. I certainly wouldn't forget that. You'd never forgive me.  As a matter of fact, I sent him a telegram myself...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Don't get up. And please stop acting as if I were the queen mother.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to-

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: If you'd like.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I wouldn't like.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'd like to hear it.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Some snowy night in front of the fire... in the meantime, while we're on the subject, will you check about the hors d'oeuvres? The caterer forgot them, the varnish wasn't dry or something...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: The hors d'oeuvres are here. Is there anything else I can do?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Thank you, Eve. I'd like a Martini - very dry.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Good evening, Mr. deWitt.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I had no idea you knew each other.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Terribly sorry I'm late, lunch was long and I couldn't find a cab - where's Miss Caswell, shall we start? Oh, hello, Eve...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Hello, Miss Channing.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: How are you making out in Mr. Fabian's office?  I don't want you working the child too hard, Max - just because you promised. As you see, I kept my promise, too...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Miss Channing, I can't tell you how glad I am that you arrived so late.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Really, Eve? Why?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Well, if you'd been here to begin with, I wouldn't have dared to read at all...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... and if you'd come in the middle, I'd have stopped, I couldn't have gone on-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What a pity, all that fire and music being turned off...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Hi.  Hello, darling-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Hi.  "Well, now Mis' Channin', ah don't think you can rightly say we lost the wah, we was mo' stahved out, you might say - an' that's what ah don' unnerstand about all these plays about love-stahved Suth'n women - love is one thing we was nevah stahved for the South!"

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It's the tight girdle that does it.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I find these wisecracks increasingly less funny! 'Aged in Wood' happens to be a fine and distinguished play-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Relax, kid. It's only me and my big mouth...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: It's just that you get me so mad sometimes... of all the women in the world with nothing to complain about-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Ain't it the truth?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Yes, it is! You're talented, famous, wealthy - people waiting around night after night just to see you, even in the wind and rain...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Autograph fiends! They're not people - those little beast who run in packs like coyotes-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: They're your fans, your audience-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: They're nobody's fans! They're juvenile delinquents, mental detectives, they're nobody's audience, they never see a play or a movie, even - they're never indoors long enough!

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Well... there's one indoors now. I've brought her back to see you.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You've what?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: She's just outside the door.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: The heave-ho.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Dear Birdie. Won't you sit down, Miss Worthington?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Harrington.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I'm so sorry... Harrington. Won't you sit down?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Would you like a drink? It's right beside you...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I was telling Margo and Lloyd about how often you'd seen the play...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Margo, really...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Please don't play governess, Karen, I haven't your unyielding good taste, I wish I'd gone to Radcliffe too but father wouldn't hear of it - he needed help at the notions counter...  I'm being rude now, aren't I? OR should I say "ain't I"?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Margo, nothing you've ever done has made me as happy as your taking Eve in...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I'm so happy you're happy.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: That little place just two hours form New York. It's on my list of things-I'll-never-understand. Like collecting shrunken Indian heads...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Of all people you should know what it means to want some peace and quiet-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Peace and quit is for libraries.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: How much time have we?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Roughly ten minutes.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: How far to the station?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Three or four miles...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Any houses or farms around where we can borrow gas?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: None in sight, there aren't many along this back road...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Not many car either, not much chance of a lift...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: He always looks so pathetic whenever he does anything physical-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It seems to me that walking, for most people, is not very dangerous.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I just never think of Lloyd as anywhere but indoors and anything but sitting down.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Be brave. He'll come back - with or without gas.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Do you want it on?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: It doesn't matter.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I detest cheap sentiment.
